headline: Car Found in Georgia Pond May Be That of a New York Couple Missing Since 1980
abstract: The Romers, of Scarsdale, N.Y., disappeared from a Georgia hotel. Divers who seek to solve cold cases found a vehicle similar to theirs in a pond. They also found bones.
lead_paragraph: Charles Romer, a retired oil company executive from Scarsdale, N.Y., and his wife, Catherine, were driving back from their winter home in Florida in the spring of 1980 when they stopped at a Holiday Inn in Georgia.
snippet: The Romers, of Scarsdale, N.Y., disappeared from a Georgia hotel. Divers who seek to solve cold cases found a vehicle similar to theirs in a pond. They also found bones.

lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on President-elect Trump’s transition.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 27, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Nov. 27, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about a painting by René Magritte selling for over $100 million at auction referred incorrectly to Paolo Vedovi’s relationship to the Vedovi gallery in Brussels. He is the co-founder of the gallery, not the director.
snippet: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Nov. 27, 2024.

headline: Hammer’s End
abstract: Jill Singer’s triple words score.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
snippet: Jill Singer’s triple words score.

headline: Meet One of Hong Kong’s Last Remaining Pro-Democracy Activists
abstract: For Chan Po-ying, a labor rights leader, life is one of constant police surveillance, even on hikes. But she finds solace from tiny gestures of support.
lead_paragraph: When a court in Hong Kong sentenced 45 pro-democracy politicians and activists to prison sentences of up to 10 years, it took down the city’s once-vocal opposition in one fell swoop, making clear the risks of dissent.
snippet: For Chan Po-ying, a labor rights leader, life is one of constant police surveillance, even on hikes. But she finds solace from tiny gestures of support.

headline: Will Namibia’s Liberation Party Be the Next to Fall in Africa?
abstract: Voters head to the polls on Wednesday in the latest test for one of southern Africa’s liberation parties, which have been rebuked at the ballot box this year.
lead_paragraph: Voters in southern Africa this year have delivered blow after blow to parties that helped free their countries from colonialism. And on Wednesday, one of those parties, the South West Africa People’s Organization, or SWAPO, in Namibia is expected to face its toughest electoral test ever.
snippet: Voters head to the polls on Wednesday in the latest test for one of southern Africa’s liberation parties, which have been rebuked at the ballot box this year.

headline: ‘Mr. Every Man’: The 50 Others Accused in France’s Mass Rape Trial
abstract: Dominique Pelicot invited men to rape his wife, whom he had drugged. The French media call them “Mr. Every Man” because they come from such ordinary backgrounds.
lead_paragraph: The last of 50 men to be cross-examined in the rape of a drugged and naked Gisèle Pelicot stood before the judges in a white sweater and jeans.
snippet: Dominique Pelicot invited men to rape his wife, whom he had drugged. The French media call them “Mr. Every Man” because they come from such ordinary backgrounds.

headline: Britain’s Emotional Debate Over Assisted Dying
abstract: As lawmakers prepare to vote on legalizing assisted suicide for the terminally ill in England and Wales, an intense public discussion has unfolded.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Tarlow had a sense that something was wrong as soon as she opened her front door and called out to her bedridden husband upstairs. There was no reply. Instead of the sound of the radio that normally echoed from his room, the house was engulfed in silence.
snippet: As lawmakers prepare to vote on legalizing assisted suicide for the terminally ill in England and Wales, an intense public discussion has unfolded.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: A cease-fire agreement between Israel and Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli cabinet yesterday approved a cease-fire proposal that would stop the fighting between Israel and Hezbollah, the Lebanese militant group. The fighting has displaced over a million Lebanese and tens of thousands of Israelis, killed more than 3,000 Lebanese and 100 Israelis and upended the regional balance of power. See maps that show how the deal will work.
snippet: A cease-fire agreement between Israel and Hezbollah.

headline: Ireland Is Rich. That Doesn’t Mean It’s Happy.
abstract: There are the same dark subplots here that have made the position of other incumbent governments so precarious.
lead_paragraph: Ireland’s current condition might best be described as an embarrassment of riches. A country that was long one of the poorest in Western Europe now has an abundance of public and private wealth and an economy that is open to the world. It has even proved relatively resistant to the temptation of the far right that has proved so appealing elsewhere; perhaps nostalgia for an imagined golden age doesn’t hold much appeal when memories of poverty, mass emigration and the repression imposed by conservative Catholicism are so fresh in the minds of a well-educated, socially liberal population.
snippet: There are the same dark subplots here that have made the position of other incumbent governments so precarious.

headline: Word of the Day: eminent domain
abstract: This term has appeared in 15 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word eminent domain has appeared in 15 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 3 in “A Climate Change Success Story? Look at Hoboken” by Michael Kimmelman:
snippet: This term has appeared in 15 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Doubts Trump’s Grasp of Economics
abstract: Kimmel called the president-elect’s plan to hit Mexico, Canada and China with sweeping tariffs “the dumbest thing he’s come up with since Don Jr.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
snippet: Kimmel called the president-elect’s plan to hit Mexico, Canada and China with sweeping tariffs “the dumbest thing he’s come up with since Don Jr.”

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
snippet: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.

headline: Why a Pasture-Raised Thanksgiving Turkey Costs $95
abstract: Humanely raised turkeys are often more expensive because they eat high-quality food, require more space, and take extra time to raise.
lead_paragraph: The turkeys at Troll Bridge Farm are pasture-raised, and Lisa Skillman, who runs the farm with her husband and four of their six children, said she works hard to keep the birds as natural as possible. Their beaks aren’t cut and their toes aren’t clipped, practices often used on farms owned by large corporations.
snippet: Humanely raised turkeys are often more expensive because they eat high-quality food, require more space, and take extra time to raise.

headline: Escape From New York? For Thanksgiving, You Have to Have a Plan.
abstract: Getting to any of the airports that serve New York City can take too long or cost too much. Devising a way to ease the journey is its own holiday ritual.
lead_paragraph: Every year around this time, thousands of New Yorkers engage in an intricate Thanksgiving ritual that involves advanced calculations, complex analytics, risk-assessment and strategic thinking.
snippet: Getting to any of the airports that serve New York City can take too long or cost too much. Devising a way to ease the journey is its own holiday ritual.

headline: On Big Pharma, Food and Agriculture, These Are Kennedy’s Unexpected Bedfellows
abstract: When it comes to weeding out corporate influence, Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s ideas often align best with some of Trump’s loudest critics.
lead_paragraph: There is no denying the bromance between President-elect Donald J. Trump and Robert F. Kennedy Jr., two men with famously big egos and a desire to expose what they view as a corrupt federal bureaucracy.
snippet: When it comes to weeding out corporate influence, Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s ideas often align best with some of Trump’s loudest critics.

headline: Travel Day
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this photo, or describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
snippet: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.

headline: The Sidewalk Fruit Vendor Who Sold a $6.2 Million Banana for 25 Cents
abstract: A 74-year-old immigrant who works outside Sotheby’s shares a basement in the Bronx and works 12-hour shifts. He was stunned to hear what his banana went for at auction.
lead_paragraph: At the fruit stand where he works on Manhattan’s Upper East Side, Shah Alam sells dozens of bananas a day at 35 cents a piece, or four for a dollar. He does a brisk business in cheap fruit outside Sotheby’s auction house; inside, art can sell for millions.
snippet: A 74-year-old immigrant who works outside Sotheby’s shares a basement in the Bronx and works 12-hour shifts. He was stunned to hear what his banana went for at auction.

headline: Record November Snowfall Hits Seoul
abstract: The first snowfall of the season grounded flights and triggered a weather warning throughout the South Korean capital.
lead_paragraph: The first snowfall of the season grounded flights and triggered a weather warning throughout the South Korean capital.
snippet: The first snowfall of the season grounded flights and triggered a weather warning throughout the South Korean capital.

headline: Volkswagen to Exit China’s Xinjiang Region After 12 Years
abstract: The automaker has long been criticized by human rights activists for doing business in the territory, where China has repressed Muslim ethnic groups.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen said on Wednesday that it was disposing of its ownership stakes in facilities in northwestern China’s Xinjiang region, exiting an area now known for the country’s crackdown on predominantly Muslim ethnic groups there.
snippet: The automaker has long been criticized by human rights activists for doing business in the territory, where China has repressed Muslim ethnic groups.

headline: Pakistan Arrests Hundreds in Crackdown on Protests Backing Ex-Leader
abstract: Thousands of demonstrators seeking the release of Imran Khan, the jailed ex-prime minister, fled the capital.
lead_paragraph: More than 600 people were arrested in an overnight crackdown on supporters of Pakistan’s jailed former prime minister in Islamabad, the police said on Wednesday.
snippet: Thousands of demonstrators seeking the release of Imran Khan, the jailed ex-prime minister, fled the capital.

headline: Record Snowfall Hurls Seoul Into Winter
abstract: The heaviest November snowstorm on record in the South Korean capital was a nuisance to commuters, and a delight to tourists, children and dogs.
lead_paragraph: For many people in Seoul, a record November snowfall on Wednesday felt like a sudden plunge into winter, when days earlier they had been enjoying unseasonably warm temperatures.
snippet: The heaviest November snowstorm on record in the South Korean capital was a nuisance to commuters, and a delight to tourists, children and dogs.

headline: Battle of the Mega-Ships? A European Behemoth Heads to the Caribbean.
abstract: The new MSC World America will arrive in spring, joining other huge ships. Be prepared for a strong European influence when it comes to design and food.
lead_paragraph: At the Chantiers de l’Atlantique shipyard on the west coast of France, MSC World America is the latest mega cruise ship to near completion. Scheduled to cross the Atlantic in March, the vessel will be based in Miami, where it will offer Caribbean itineraries and take on the likes of Royal Caribbean’s Icon of the Seas and Carnival’s Celebration.
snippet: The new MSC World America will arrive in spring, joining other huge ships. Be prepared for a strong European influence when it comes to design and food.

headline: Overlooked No More: Margaret Getchell, Visionary Force at Macy’s
abstract: As the store’s first female executive, she helped turn it into what it is today, paving the way for other women to hold senior positions in retail.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
snippet: As the store’s first female executive, she helped turn it into what it is today, paving the way for other women to hold senior positions in retail.

headline: The Most Important Conversation to Have Before You Die
abstract: Talking about your advance care directive with your loved ones will make life — and death — easier later on.
lead_paragraph: Instead of talking about politics around the Thanksgiving table this year, consider a less fraught topic: death.
snippet: Talking about your advance care directive with your loved ones will make life — and death — easier later on.

headline: Airlines Are Padding Flight Times. It’s Not Your Imagination.
abstract: Flying in America has become slower even as official statistics have shown improvement.
lead_paragraph: The average flight today from Kennedy Airport to LAX is slower than it was in 1995 in every conceivable way. Planes face longer delays leaving the gate; take more time taxiing before taking off; and spend more time in the air.
snippet: Flying in America has become slower even as official statistics have shown improvement.

headline: The Land That Allowed Ken Burns to Raise the Dead
abstract: The award-winning filmmaker has slept in the same bedroom for over four decades. He credits his home with allowing him to make the films everyone said he couldn’t.
lead_paragraph: Ken Burns has slept in the same bedroom for the past 45 years.
snippet: The award-winning filmmaker has slept in the same bedroom for over four decades. He credits his home with allowing him to make the films everyone said he couldn’t.

headline: Lauren Mayberry of Chvrches Is Making a Statement on Her Own
abstract: The singer and songwriter has fronted the Glaswegian band for 13 years. Next month, she’s going solo on “Vicious Creature,” an ambitious and emotional pop odyssey.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Mayberry was in the bunk of her band’s tour bus in the winter of 2021, rolling between Denver and Boulder, Colo., when she started wondering how old Gwen Stefani was when she released her first solo record.
snippet: The singer and songwriter has fronted the Glaswegian band for 13 years. Next month, she’s going solo on “Vicious Creature,” an ambitious and emotional pop odyssey.

headline: How ‘September 5’ Recreates a Historic News Broadcast
abstract: The drama chronicles the 1972 Munich Olympics attack from ABC Sports’ point of view, a perspective that resonates today. But the film arrives at a fraught time.
lead_paragraph: “They’re all gone.”
snippet: The drama chronicles the 1972 Munich Olympics attack from ABC Sports’ point of view, a perspective that resonates today. But the film arrives at a fraught time.

headline: With ‘The Piano Lesson,’ Danielle Deadwyler Goes Even Deeper
abstract: After breaking through with “Till,” the actress delivers another formidable performance. Still, when it comes to Hollywood, she’d rather keep some distance.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Sunday morning in West Hollywood, the actress Danielle Deadwyler wore all white, clad in a pristine Tory Burch dress.
snippet: After breaking through with “Till,” the actress delivers another formidable performance. Still, when it comes to Hollywood, she’d rather keep some distance.

headline: 9 Books Coming in December
abstract: A Hitchcockian thriller, an off-the-grid memoir, novels by Weike Wang and Lily Tuck, and more.
lead_paragraph: In the third novel by the author of “Chemistry” and “Joan Is Okay,” Keru and Nate, an interracial, young professional couple, host their parents on consecutive vacations at a rented beach house in New England and a Catskills bungalow. As the visits gradually expose resentments and longings they would rather keep hidden — Keru is the daughter of strict, highly driven Chinese immigrants; Nate is the first in his white, working-class family to earn a college degree — Wang paints an elegantly off-kilter portrait of partnership and its isolations, and of the ungainly, imperfect intimacy of family.
snippet: A Hitchcockian thriller, an off-the-grid memoir, novels by Weike Wang and Lily Tuck, and more.

headline: Kim Hill Is Building Her Seat at the Table
abstract: After walking away from the Black Eyed Peas, the artist and designer has been making work on her own terms.
lead_paragraph: Before the Black Eyed Peas were a stadium act fronted by Will.i.am and Fergie, they were a trio of quirky Los Angeles-based rappers who often collaborated with Black female singers. Macy Gray, best known for her 1999 hit “I Try,” sang on their first two albums, released in 1998 and 2000. But their closest female collaborator in those days was Kim Hill.
snippet: After walking away from the Black Eyed Peas, the artist and designer has been making work on her own terms.

headline: Inside a Legendary New York Hotel, a Home With Wall-to-Wall Tiger Print
abstract: How a full floor of the Sherry-Netherland became an apartment that evokes both European grandeur and downtown lofts.
lead_paragraph: “IT HAS THE spirit of a loft,” says the interior designer Martin Brûlé, surveying the apartment that inhabits an entire floor of the Sherry-Netherland, the 38-story Jazz Age Fifth Avenue co-op and hotel overlooking Central Park at 59th Street. “The stereotype of a New York loft is that it’s downtown with this artsy feeling, mismatched furniture. Well, this space has all those elements. It’s just a completely dreamy version of that.”
snippet: How a full floor of the Sherry-Netherland became an apartment that evokes both European grandeur and downtown lofts.

headline: As a Couples Therapist, I See the Same Destructive Patterns in Our Political Discourse
abstract: We’re in a national moment of great fear and suspicion. But the principles of psychoanalysis that can help feuding couples can also help us reconcile our differences.
lead_paragraph: Louisa and Isaac, a lively, warm and bright couple in their 40s, fell in love two decades ago. They were intellectually engaged with each other, adventurous and, for years, shared “deep blue” affiliations. That changed during Donald Trump’s first term.
snippet: We’re in a national moment of great fear and suspicion. But the principles of psychoanalysis that can help feuding couples can also help us reconcile our differences.

headline: The Biggest Travel Debate: Check In or Carry On?
abstract: Check in or carry on? Amy Virshup, the Travel editor at The New York Times, and Christine Chung, a Times reporter covering consumer travel, have a debate.
lead_paragraph: Check in or carry on? Amy Virshup, the Travel editor at The New York Times, and Christine Chung, a Times reporter covering consumer travel, have a debate.
snippet: Check in or carry on? Amy Virshup, the Travel editor at The New York Times, and Christine Chung, a Times reporter covering consumer travel, have a debate.

headline: What Exactly Is Morning Mist? And Other Questions.
abstract: In “The Miraculous From the Material,” the best-selling author Alan Lightman examines the science behind the wonder.
lead_paragraph: You are on a run early one winter morning and come to a favorite meadow where a layer of mist lies across the grass like a sheet of tissue over a box of new clothes. But why is it there? What is the mist? Why has the cold night summoned it? Why does it keep within such defined boundaries? And why does it melt away as the sun rises?
snippet: In “The Miraculous From the Material,” the best-selling author Alan Lightman examines the science behind the wonder.

headline: French Toast Gets a Polynesian Pick Me Up
abstract: Ipo, Tahitian coconut bread, takes the place of toasty French bread, merging long histories.
lead_paragraph: In Fiji, when breadfruit trees bear more fruit than usual, it is at once a gift and a warning sign: Hurricane season will be dire. As a child, Robert Oliver watched people bury the fruit in pits lined with banana leaves. After the storms passed, they dug them up, now fermented, and put them straight on the fire to cook. This was how generations survived. Reportedly, breadfruit from a pit dating back three centuries was discovered to be still edible — to have defied time.
snippet: Ipo, Tahitian coconut bread, takes the place of toasty French bread, merging long histories.

headline: I Haul, Therefore I Am
abstract: It is the shopping phenomenon of our times, and now it’s an Amazon store.
lead_paragraph: In mid-November, as election post-mortems focused on inflation worries and the holiday shopping season began to pick up steam, Amazon introduced a new storefront.
snippet: It is the shopping phenomenon of our times, and now it’s an Amazon store.

headline: In ‘Yuletide Factory,’ Cirque Mechanics Manufactures a Family Holiday Show
abstract: It’s Christmas at the sweatshop, but the mood fluctuates between ho ho ho and ho hum.
lead_paragraph: Since the 1840s, some people have complained about the commercialization of Christmas. Others have embraced it. “Yuletide Factory,” a circus show at the New Victory Theater, splits the difference, locating its cheer inside a sweatshop churning out seasonal doodads. Nothing says Christmas like a repetitive stress injury?
snippet: It’s Christmas at the sweatshop, but the mood fluctuates between ho ho ho and ho hum.

headline: ‘Moana 2’ Review: It Doesn’t Rock the Boat
abstract: In this benign sequel, the Disney princess continues her seafaring ways and remains admirably uninterested in finding a prince.
lead_paragraph: “Moana,” Disney’s breezy foray into Polynesian myth and culture, was released almost exactly eight years ago. Anyone remember what was going on that month? Amid an election, a reckoning and political anxiety, Moana’s anthems about voyaging beyond the confines of her coral reef (the tropical version of a glass ceiling) to save her people from environmental disaster rang out with special feeling.
snippet: In this benign sequel, the Disney princess continues her seafaring ways and remains admirably uninterested in finding a prince.

headline: ‘The Seed of the Sacred Fig’ Review: When the World Is a Prison
abstract: Mohammad Rasoulof’s powerful drama about the authoritarian Iranian government breaks a fourth wall, with consequences.
lead_paragraph: The ubiquity of smartphones capable of filming anything, anywhere, has been a blessing and a curse to autocratic governments. On the one hand, protests and nascent revolutions can be filmed and broadcast, seen around the world, making the authoritarian’s attempt to quash dissent much more onerous.
snippet: Mohammad Rasoulof’s powerful drama about the authoritarian Iranian government breaks a fourth wall, with consequences.

headline: Family and Friends in Town? Here’s What to Watch Based on the Mood.
abstract: Whether you’re with hanging out with children or adults, want to laugh or tuck into an adventure, here are some specific selections to stream.
lead_paragraph: “What do you all want to watch?”
snippet: Whether you’re with hanging out with children or adults, want to laugh or tuck into an adventure, here are some specific selections to stream.

headline: How the World’s Largest Democracy Slid Toward Authoritarianism
abstract: “The New India,” by Rahul Bhatia, combines personal history and investigative journalism to account for his country’s turn to militant Hindu nationalism.
lead_paragraph: Rahul Bhatia’s new book began from bewilderment: He wanted to know what was happening to the people he loved.
snippet: “The New India,” by Rahul Bhatia, combines personal history and investigative journalism to account for his country’s turn to militant Hindu nationalism.

headline: Lovable Movie Robots Are Coming to Charm Your Children
abstract: The adult world is ever more full of robots. Children’s entertainment feels as if it’s working hard to make them seem adorable.
lead_paragraph: One near certainty about raising a young child these days is that you and your offspring will be exposed to a lot of stories about robots. Another is that the robots working their charms most effectively on you will belong to a new kind of archetype: the sympathetic robot. Sitting in darkened theaters with my 5-year-old son, I have watched any number of these characters. They are openhearted and often dazzled by the wonders of everyday life — innocently astounded by, say, the freedom of playing in the surf, the bliss of dancing with a loved one or the thrill of just holding hands. They might be more winningly human than some of the humans you know.
snippet: The adult world is ever more full of robots. Children’s entertainment feels as if it’s working hard to make them seem adorable.

headline: A Stray Dog Climbed an Egyptian Pyramid. Along Came a Paraglider.
abstract: A video of a dog on a pyramid took off on social media — but only after it was appropriated and doctored.
lead_paragraph: They say that every dog has its day, and for Apollo, a young stray who roams the Giza necropolis in Greater Cairo, that day was Oct. 14. Just after sunrise, a paraglider pilot named Alex Lang spied the dog frolicking atop the Pyramid of Khafre, a 448-foot-tall limestone monument in the famous Giza complex that people are not permitted to scale.
snippet: A video of a dog on a pyramid took off on social media — but only after it was appropriated and doctored.

headline: How to Help Those Still Devastated by Hurricane Helene
abstract: Natural disasters call to our shared humanity.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Times Opinion’s Giving Guide 2024. Read more in a note from Times Opinion’s editor, Kathleen Kingsbury.
snippet: Natural disasters call to our shared humanity.

headline: The MAGA Science Agenda Reveals America’s Future
abstract: If there’s a thread tying this coalition together, it’s suspicion of expertise and elitism.
lead_paragraph: The leader of the Republican Party and our country’s next president has tapped a pro-choice scion of the country’s most famous Democratic dynasty to lead the Department of Health and Human Services. In keeping with the bewildering dynamics of today’s negative partisanship, conservative groups such as the Heritage Foundation have cheered the selection of Robert F. Kennedy Jr., while liberals have near categorically denounced him.
snippet: If there’s a thread tying this coalition together, it’s suspicion of expertise and elitism.

headline: A Housing Crisis Deepens, and a Reporter Digs In
abstract: To really communicate with people about the many problems arrayed across the housing landscape, we needed to cut through the noise.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic disoriented us in many ways. In New York City, one of the most dizzying changes was a rental rate boomerang between 2020 and 2022. First, apartment rates dropped steeply, and many renters celebrated the pandemic deals they had secured in high-demand neighborhoods. Soon enough, though, rents shot back up with renewed vigor, sending the cost of living in New York, America’s biggest city, to even more stratospheric levels. By June 2022, the average monthly rent on a new lease in Manhattan had risen above a staggering $5,000.
snippet: To really communicate with people about the many problems arrayed across the housing landscape, we needed to cut through the noise.

headline: Thomas Friedman: Trump’s Path to a Nobel Peace Prize?
abstract: How the president-elect could change the Middle East — for the better.
lead_paragraph: The Israel-Gaza war poses multiple challenges for President-elect Donald Trump’s new administration. But the former president has proposed a plan for peace in the region before. The question is: can he be convinced to pursue it again? In this episode, the columnist Thomas L. Friedman argues that Trump has an opportunity to make history.
snippet: How the president-elect could change the Middle East — for the better.

headline: These Thanksgiving Heroes Love to Talk Turkey
abstract: Follow four experts at the Butterball Turkey Talk-Line as they get ready for their biggest day.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving has many heroes, but the Butterball Turkey Talk-Line may be the largest gathering of them all in one office space.
snippet: Follow four experts at the Butterball Turkey Talk-Line as they get ready for their biggest day.

headline: At Thanksgiving Time, It’s Raining on Macy’s Parade
abstract: The forecast is bad for the famous parade on Thursday. But that’s not Macy’s only problem.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look ahead to the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade and why Macy’s has more to worry about than bad weather. We’ll also get details on why City Hall is rushing to close a migrant shelter in Brooklyn before President-elect Donald Trump takes office in January.
snippet: The forecast is bad for the famous parade on Thursday. But that’s not Macy’s only problem.

headline: Inside the Plastic Industry’s Battle to Win Over Hearts and Minds
abstract: Documents leaked from an industry group show how plastics companies are pushing back against a “tide of anti-plastic sentiment.”
lead_paragraph: Paid influencers on TikTok. An infomercial hosted by Dennis Quaid. Pushback against the Olympics’ single-use plastic ban.
snippet: Documents leaked from an industry group show how plastics companies are pushing back against a “tide of anti-plastic sentiment.”

headline: America’s Great Unifying Event: The Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade
abstract: The nostalgia-fueled production has been the most-watched entertainment program in the United States for the past three years, ahead of the Oscars and the World Series.
lead_paragraph: It might be the kookiest three and a half hours in all of television.
snippet: The nostalgia-fueled production has been the most-watched entertainment program in the United States for the past three years, ahead of the Oscars and the World Series.

headline: $400,000 Homes in Michigan, Pennsylvania and Vermont
abstract: A five-bedroom Tudor Revival house in Detroit, a 1925 rowhouse in South Philadelphia, and a two-bedroom cottage from 1920 in Manchester, Vt.
lead_paragraph: This five-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bathroom house in Detroit’s North End has undergone an extensive remodel beginning in 2017, with additions including new windows, new HVAC, plumbing and electrical systems, and a new deck. Paint inside and out is also new, and the sellers turned the attic into more living space, complete with a full bathroom.
snippet: A five-bedroom Tudor Revival house in Detroit, a 1925 rowhouse in South Philadelphia, and a two-bedroom cottage from 1920 in Manchester, Vt.

headline: Record Number of Travelers Expected Over Thanksgiving Week
abstract: Bad weather threatens roads over the holiday, but airports have had little trouble on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Marvin Scott usually gets to the airport about 45 minutes before his flights, but on Wednesday, he arrived at Kennedy International Airport in New York two hours early, aware that experts had warned that this Thanksgiving travel week would be the busiest ever.
snippet: Bad weather threatens roads over the holiday, but airports have had little trouble on Wednesday.

headline: What Is Russia’s Oreshnik Ballistic Missile?
abstract: The weapon used for the first time against Ukraine last week is capable of carrying nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: The dust has settled in Dnipro, Ukraine, where investigators are analyzing the wreckage at a weapons factory struck by a new Russian intermediate-range ballistic missile last week. But the debate continues over the strategic impact of the missile, known as the Oreshnik, both on the battlefield in Ukraine and what it means for NATO states in Europe.
snippet: The weapon used for the first time against Ukraine last week is capable of carrying nuclear weapons.

headline: Maine Becomes the Latest State to Sue Oil Companies Over Climate Change
abstract: In a new lawsuit, the state’s attorney general claims oil companies deceived the public about fossil fuel products’ contributions to climate change.
lead_paragraph: Maine has become the latest state to sue oil and gas companies over climate change, claiming that Exxon Mobil, Shell, Chevron and other giants waged a decades-long campaign to conceal the effects of fossil fuels and contributed to the extreme weather that has pummeled the state in recent years.
snippet: In a new lawsuit, the state’s attorney general claims oil companies deceived the public about fossil fuel products’ contributions to climate change.

headline: Kentucky Auction of Confiscated Alcohol Includes Rare Bourbon Bottles
abstract: A new state law grants the Kentucky Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control the authority to auction off impounded alcohol.
lead_paragraph: Kentucky bourbon fans could be giving thanks this week as the state auctions off some rare confiscated bottles.
snippet: A new state law grants the Kentucky Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control the authority to auction off impounded alcohol.

headline: Two Presidents, Two Policies, One Superpower: America in Transition
abstract: Even as President Biden brokers a cease-fire in Lebanon, President-elect Donald J. Trump is running his own foreign policy without waiting to be sworn in.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on President-elect Trump’s transition.
snippet: Even as President Biden brokers a cease-fire in Lebanon, President-elect Donald J. Trump is running his own foreign policy without waiting to be sworn in.

headline: When Leniency Is the Goal, a Justice System Breaks Easily
abstract: Two recent cases show New York’s fragile courts have little room for error.
lead_paragraph: Last week was not a good one for New York’s sense of public safety. That Monday a man with two knives roamed across Manhattan and is now accused of killing three strangers — Angel Gustavo Lata Landi, Chang Wang and Wilma Augustin — in separate attacks. The next day a man with a gun reportedly robbed a Queens bodega and a smoke shop before being fatally shot by the police after he shot and wounded an officer and a bystander.
snippet: Two recent cases show New York’s fragile courts have little room for error.

headline: Chinese Automakers Tell Suppliers to Cut Costs as Price War Deepens
abstract: China’s electric vehicle market is the world’s largest — and its most cutthroat, with dozens of brands jostling for position.
lead_paragraph: Faced with a bruising price war in the fast growing but crowded domestic market for electric vehicles, Chinese automobile manufacturers are pressuring suppliers to deliver hefty cost cuts.
snippet: China’s electric vehicle market is the world’s largest — and its most cutthroat, with dozens of brands jostling for position.

headline: Will Lebanon Deal Break Gaza Deadlock? Experts Doubt It
abstract: Hamas is unlikely to compromise in Gaza, despite the decision by its ally, Hezbollah, to stop fighting. A deal in Gaza would also be harder for Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister.
lead_paragraph: Buoyant after helping to forge a cease-fire in Lebanon, President Biden has declared that the deal could build momentum toward a similar breakthrough in Gaza.
snippet: Hamas is unlikely to compromise in Gaza, despite the decision by its ally, Hezbollah, to stop fighting. A deal in Gaza would also be harder for Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 536
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Nov. 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
snippet: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Nov. 28, 2024.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,258
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Nov. 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
snippet: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Nov. 28, 2024.

headline: How Israel Uses Palestinian Detainees as Human Shields
abstract: An investigation into an Israeli tactic in Gaza, and what it reveals about the nature of the war there.
lead_paragraph: Overnight, Israel agreed to a cease-fire with the Lebanese armed group Hezbollah — a major turning point in one of the wars the country has been fighting since Hamas attacked it on Oct. 7. But the war in Gaza shows no sign of ending, and Israel’s conduct there is coming under increased scrutiny.
snippet: An investigation into an Israeli tactic in Gaza, and what it reveals about the nature of the war there.

headline: A Fragile Israel-Hezbollah Truce, and a Push to Make You Love Plastic
abstract: Plus, the A.I. granny scamming the scammers.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:
snippet: Plus, the A.I. granny scamming the scammers.

headline: Northern Israel Residents ‘Don’t Know What We Will Be Returning To’ After Cease-Fire
abstract: Some of the tens of thousands of Israelis displaced by the war with Hezbollah worried whether it was safe to go home.
lead_paragraph: When Odie Arbel saw news reports that Israel and Hezbollah had agreed to a cease-fire, he felt a mix of relief and worry about the prospect of returning to Kibbutz Yiftah, just over a mile from the Israeli-Lebanese border.
snippet: Some of the tens of thousands of Israelis displaced by the war with Hezbollah worried whether it was safe to go home.

headline: With Joy and Tears, Lebanese Return Home: ‘Look at All the Destruction’
abstract: A cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah allowed those displaced by the war to return to their homes. Many found buildings cleaved in half, crushed cars and ruined towns.
lead_paragraph: As day broke on the newly established cease-fire between Hezbollah and Israel on Wednesday, Hussein Nassour returned to his Beirut neighborhood to inspect the ruins of his former life.
snippet: A cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah allowed those displaced by the war to return to their homes. Many found buildings cleaved in half, crushed cars and ruined towns.

headline: Donald Trump’s Immigration Plans
abstract: We explore Trump’s mass deportation goals.
lead_paragraph: Imagine the population of Chicago. Then quadruple it. That’s about how many unauthorized immigrants Donald Trump hopes to remove from the country: 11 million people in all.
snippet: We explore Trump’s mass deportation goals.

headline: Theater to See in N.Y.C. This Holiday Season
abstract: “Elf the Musical,” inventive spins on “A Christmas Carol” and classic family fare: Here are some of our favorite shows of the season.
lead_paragraph: The end of the year marks the return of eggnog and latkes, gifting and regifting — and holiday-themed shows to bask in tradition, communal spirit and, yes, fun. In New York, we can always count on well-timed offerings on stages of all sizes.
snippet: “Elf the Musical,” inventive spins on “A Christmas Carol” and classic family fare: Here are some of our favorite shows of the season.

headline: I.C.C. Prosecutor Seeks Arrest Warrant for Myanmar Junta Leader
abstract: The International Criminal Court’s chief prosecutor accused Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing of crimes against humanity toward the country’s Muslim Rohingya.
lead_paragraph: The chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court on Wednesday sought an arrest warrant for the country’s army leader, Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing, accusing him of crimes against humanity linked to the persecution and deportations of the Muslim Rohingya.
snippet: The International Criminal Court’s chief prosecutor accused Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing of crimes against humanity toward the country’s Muslim Rohingya.

headline: Cease-Fire Deal Leaves Beleaguered Palestinians in Gaza Feeling Forgotten
abstract: With a truce between Israel and Hezbollah taking hold, Gazans are losing hope that Israel’s war in the enclave will end anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: As a tenuous cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah began to take hold early Wednesday, some Palestinians in Gaza said they felt forgotten, nearly 14 months into a war that has shattered the enclave and killed tens of thousands of Gazans.
snippet: With a truce between Israel and Hezbollah taking hold, Gazans are losing hope that Israel’s war in the enclave will end anytime soon.

headline: Mystery Drones Spotted Over U.S. Air Bases in Britain
abstract: Small, unmanned craft were seen flying over four bases in England, the U.S. Air Force in Europe said. The Pentagon said that there had not been “any significant mission impact.”
lead_paragraph: Unidentified drones have been spotted flying over four bases used by the United States Air Force in Britain, prompting the British government to call in military staff to help protect the sites.
snippet: Small, unmanned craft were seen flying over four bases in England, the U.S. Air Force in Europe said. The Pentagon said that there had not been “any significant mission impact.”

headline: Inflation is Back in Focus as Trumponomics Looms Large Over Global Trade
abstract: Investors are bracing for the latest data as the president-elect’s economic agenda of cutting immigration and taxes, while raising tariffs takes shape.
lead_paragraph: The inflation risk stalking the markets eased over the summer, but it never really went away. It’s front and center again as investors contend with a Trumponomics crackdown on immigration, a rising trade-war risk and a potential bonanza of tax cuts.
snippet: Investors are bracing for the latest data as the president-elect’s economic agenda of cutting immigration and taxes, while raising tariffs takes shape.

headline: What to Know About the Israel-Hezbollah Cease-Fire
abstract: Under the agreement, Israel will gradually withdraw its forces from Lebanon over the next 60 days, and Hezbollah will not entrench itself near the Israeli border.
lead_paragraph: A cease-fire meant to end the deadliest war in decades between Israel and the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah officially took effect early Wednesday, less than a day after President Biden announced the deal and Israel approved its terms.
snippet: Under the agreement, Israel will gradually withdraw its forces from Lebanon over the next 60 days, and Hezbollah will not entrench itself near the Israeli border.

headline: I Ran Into My Horrible Ex in My Therapist’s Waiting Room. Help!
abstract: A reader seeks advice on how to contend with the possibility of a future encounter with her ex after an explosive and painful breakup.
lead_paragraph: My ex and I broke up six months ago. It ended very badly, with lots of volatility and rage. I was so distressed by the experience that I went to therapy for the first time. It’s been helpful to recognize how much I internalized my ex’s criticisms of me. I hadn’t seen him since our breakup — until yesterday. I was sitting in my therapist’s waiting room, and he walked in with a woman who I assume is his new girlfriend. I pretended not to see him, and he walked out as soon as he saw me. The experience was alarming and mortifying: Not only has he moved on so quickly, but he’s already in couples therapy! My question: How do I avoid these run-ins in the future? I probably don’t have the right to ask him not to come to therapy during my time slot, but it’s the only time I could arrange.
snippet: A reader seeks advice on how to contend with the possibility of a future encounter with her ex after an explosive and painful breakup.

headline: Bodhi, the ‘Menswear Dog,’ Dies at 15
abstract: A Shiba Inu of uncommon sartorial panache, Bodhi modeled for Coach and was the subject of his own fashion lookbook.
lead_paragraph: Bodhi, a Shiba Inu whose smartly tailored sport coats and luxurious knitwear helped make him the rare canine men’s wear influencer, died last Monday. He was 15.
snippet: A Shiba Inu of uncommon sartorial panache, Bodhi modeled for Coach and was the subject of his own fashion lookbook.

headline: At This French Exhibition, Check Your Clothes at the Door
abstract: A museum in Marseille, France, has a show dedicated to the history of social nudity. On a few special nights, visitors strolled around naked, too.
lead_paragraph: A group of visitors listened intently to their tour guide last Friday at one of Marseille’s biggest museums. One woman examined old posters with bright colors and bold graphics. Another studied a collection of black-and-white photographs laid out on a table.
snippet: A museum in Marseille, France, has a show dedicated to the history of social nudity. On a few special nights, visitors strolled around naked, too.

headline: 3 Americans, Including F.B.I. Informant, Are Freed in Prisoner Swap With China
abstract: The Americans released, among others, a Chinese intelligence officer who was serving a 20-year sentence in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Three Americans who were detained in China have been released in a prisoner swap with Beijing, the Biden administration said on Wednesday. One of the men had been an F.B.I. informant, according to senior U.S. officials.
snippet: The Americans released, among others, a Chinese intelligence officer who was serving a 20-year sentence in the United States.

headline: Forget the Instagram Hard Launch: Are You Location-Sharing Official?
abstract: It’s the final frontier in digital expressions of coupledom. But for some people, it’s always going to be creepy.
lead_paragraph: Niara Sterling is a D.J. living in Brooklyn who frequently travels to different cities and countries to perform in front of thousands of guests at parties, concerts and other events.
snippet: It’s the final frontier in digital expressions of coupledom. But for some people, it’s always going to be creepy.

headline: The Fed’s Favorite Inflation Measure Sped Up in October
abstract: Inflation has been stubborn in recent months. Now, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s tariffs loom as a potential risk.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s preferred inflation measure sped up in October, a development that is likely to keep central bankers wary as they contemplate the path ahead for interest rates.
snippet: Inflation has been stubborn in recent months. Now, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s tariffs loom as a potential risk.

headline: What’s a Democratic Billionaire to Do Now?
abstract: The party’s donor class is still wrestling with Donald Trump’s victory, worried about retribution and sluggish liberal energy. Some rich Democrats are even pondering leaving the country.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks after Election Day, one of the biggest donors in the Democratic Party, the LinkedIn co-founder Reid Hoffman, has considered what would once have been unthinkable for a billionaire who often talks about his patriotism.
snippet: The party’s donor class is still wrestling with Donald Trump’s victory, worried about retribution and sluggish liberal energy. Some rich Democrats are even pondering leaving the country.

headline: Oxford University Names William Hague Its New Chancellor
abstract: Mr. Hague, a former leader of Britain’s Conservative Party, was chosen in a vote by his fellow alumni to lead the elite university.
lead_paragraph: The University of Oxford announced on Wednesday that William Hague, a former leader of Britain’s Conservative Party, will be its next chancellor. He narrowly beat out Elish Angiolini, who would have been the first woman in the role.
snippet: Mr. Hague, a former leader of Britain’s Conservative Party, was chosen in a vote by his fellow alumni to lead the elite university.

headline: France Suggests It Would Not Immediately Arrest Netanyahu Despite I.C.C. Warrant
abstract: The Foreign Ministry did not say outright that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel would be free to travel to France, but it argued that an I.C.C. rule on immunity may apply to him.
lead_paragraph: France’s Foreign Ministry strongly suggested on Wednesday that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel would not immediately be arrested if he came to French territory, despite an International Criminal Court arrest warrant targeting him.
snippet: The Foreign Ministry did not say outright that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel would be free to travel to France, but it argued that an I.C.C. rule on immunity may apply to him.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Couldn’t Stop Looking at Her’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: My brother and I are sitting on beige pleather chairs in a beige waiting room. Actually, we are not sitting but pacing. Our mother is very sick. The hospital has rooms where people can cry or rage (at God, the doctors), but where we go to giggle. It bubbled up in me first, prompted by the hospital’s Thanksgiving turkey carving contest. “I bet the surgeons are really good at that,” I say. “Is it a contest for surgeons?” he asks. We start writing down everything we find funny on a notepad. Then we come to this room to laugh. — Mina Bressler
snippet: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.

headline: Saving Electric Vehicles From Donald Trump
abstract: Readers offer environmental and business reasons to support E.V.s. Also: Women in the military; the Amsterdam pogrom; resentment of migrants; true crime.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
snippet: Readers offer environmental and business reasons to support E.V.s. Also: Women in the military; the Amsterdam pogrom; resentment of migrants; true crime.

headline: As Congress Feuds Over Farm Bill, Growers Are ‘Stuck in Limbo’
abstract: The agriculture and nutrition measure was last updated in 2018 and originally expired two years ago. Farmers fear the Trump administration’s priorities will eclipse theirs next year.
lead_paragraph: Congress is feuding over a new farm bill, making lawmakers likely to punt the matter for another year and leave American farmers and families on food assistance without an update to the legislation that controls how much federal support they receive.
snippet: The agriculture and nutrition measure was last updated in 2018 and originally expired two years ago. Farmers fear the Trump administration’s priorities will eclipse theirs next year.

headline: Lebanese Cheer On a Cease-Fire as Thousands Return to Their Homes
abstract: Under the cease-fire agreement, Israel will withdraw its forces from Lebanon over the next 60 days, while Hezbollah will retreat from southern Lebanon, where the Lebanese military and United Nations peacekeepers are expected to operate.
lead_paragraph: Under the cease-fire agreement, Israel will withdraw its forces from Lebanon over the next 60 days, while Hezbollah will retreat from southern Lebanon, where the Lebanese military and United Nations peacekeepers are expected to operate.
snippet: Under the cease-fire agreement, Israel will withdraw its forces from Lebanon over the next 60 days, while Hezbollah will retreat from southern Lebanon, where the Lebanese military and United Nations peacekeepers are expected to operate.

headline: A Battered and Diminished Hezbollah Accepts a Cease-Fire
abstract: Thirteen months of war left Hezbollah weakened, isolated and desperate for a way to stop the fighting.
lead_paragraph: For years, Hezbollah told the Lebanese that it alone could defend them from Israel. It boasted of powerful weapons and hardened commandos who would unleash deadly “surprises” if war broke out. And it assured its followers that a regional alliance of militias supported by Iran would jump in to support it in battle.
snippet: Thirteen months of war left Hezbollah weakened, isolated and desperate for a way to stop the fighting.

headline: ‘Wicked’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Jon M. Chu narrates a scene in “Wicked” that features the song “Popular,” with Ariana Grande and Cynthia Erivo.
lead_paragraph: The director Jon M. Chu narrates a scene in “Wicked” that features the song “Popular,” with Ariana Grande and Cynthia Erivo.
snippet: The director Jon M. Chu narrates a scene in “Wicked” that features the song “Popular,” with Ariana Grande and Cynthia Erivo.

headline: Watch Ariana Grande Swing From a Chandelier in ‘Wicked’
abstract: The director Jon M. Chu narrates the musical scene, also featuring Cynthia Erivo, where Grande performs the song “Popular.”
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
snippet: The director Jon M. Chu narrates the musical scene, also featuring Cynthia Erivo, where Grande performs the song “Popular.”

headline: Double-Pucker Cranberry Lemon Bars
abstract: Genevieve Ko’s pretty, sunset-colored treat is just the thing to offset all that tryptophan.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving is tomorrow and I have a little confession to make: I’m not cooking a turkey. I’ve got three plump duck breasts already curing in salt, garlic and herbs. Tomorrow, I’ll sear them over low heat, skin side down, until the fat renders, and then stick them in the oven just long enough for the flesh to turn from wine dark purple to deep rosy pink. It’s just the right amount for a small gathering of like-minded heretics, and we can’t wait.
snippet: Genevieve Ko’s pretty, sunset-colored treat is just the thing to offset all that tryptophan.

headline: Dinosaur Domination Is Marked in a Timeline of Vomit and Feces Fossils
abstract: Studying bromalites helped paleontologists piece together how the reptiles came to rule a part of the prehistoric world.
lead_paragraph: It was not always easy being a dinosaur. When they scampered onto the scene 230 million years ago, these “terrible lizards” were prehistoric pipsqueaks among a slew of bigger, badder reptiles brimming with teeth and bolstered with armor. But 30 million years later, many of these older reptiles were gone, and dinosaurs reigned supreme.
snippet: Studying bromalites helped paleontologists piece together how the reptiles came to rule a part of the prehistoric world.

headline: Judge Finds New York in Contempt, Clearing the Way for Rikers Takeover
abstract: The finding was a landmark in a court case that has stretched out over more than a decade. Plans for a receivership of New York City’s jails will be heard on Jan. 14.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge overseeing New York City’s Rikers Island jail complex on Wednesday found the city in contempt for failing to stem violence and excessive force at the facility, and said she was leaning toward taking control of the city’s jails.
snippet: The finding was a landmark in a court case that has stretched out over more than a decade. Plans for a receivership of New York City’s jails will be heard on Jan. 14.

headline: Hoping for Allies Among Trump’s Health Picks, Pharma Faces Hostility
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and other candidates for top health posts are at odds with the drug industry, setting the stage for tense battles over regulatory changes.
lead_paragraph: Drug company executives had hoped that a second Trump administration would be staffed by friendly health policy officials who would reduce regulation and help their industry boom.
snippet: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and other candidates for top health posts are at odds with the drug industry, setting the stage for tense battles over regulatory changes.

headline: Displaced Lebanese Rush to Return Home Following Cease-Fire
abstract: Roads were packed with cars as people displaced from southern and eastern Lebanon began returning to their homes after a cease-fire deal between Israel and Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: Roads were packed with cars as people displaced from southern and eastern Lebanon began returning to their homes after a cease-fire deal between Israel and Hezbollah.
snippet: Roads were packed with cars as people displaced from southern and eastern Lebanon began returning to their homes after a cease-fire deal between Israel and Hezbollah.

headline: ​​Tell Us Your Memories of Keiko, the Whale From ‘Free Willy’
abstract: We want to hear your stories of the beloved celebrity orca, whose real-life return to the ocean is explored in our new podcast.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1993, the movie “Free Willy” — about a captive killer whale that’s heroically set free — was an unexpected hit. But when word got out that the real whale who played Willy, an orca named Keiko, was dangerously sick and stuck in a tiny pool at an amusement park in Mexico City, fans pleaded for his release.
snippet: We want to hear your stories of the beloved celebrity orca, whose real-life return to the ocean is explored in our new podcast.

headline: China Has a New Playbook to Counter Trump: ‘Supply Chain Warfare’
abstract: A series of swipes at American companies show how China could take the initiative in a new trade war, using its economic dominance to exact pain.
lead_paragraph: In the world of cheap drones, Skydio was the great American hope. Its autonomous flying machines gave the U.S. defense and police agencies an alternative to Chinese manufacturers, free from the security concerns tied to dependence on Chinese supply chains.
snippet: A series of swipes at American companies show how China could take the initiative in a new trade war, using its economic dominance to exact pain.

headline: Andy Paley, Whose Imprint Was All Over Pop Music, Dies at 73
abstract: Musician, singer, songwriter, producer and more, he collaborated with Madonna and a raft of other artists and helped resuscitate the career of the Beach Boys’ Brian Wilson.
lead_paragraph: Andy Paley, a record producer, composer and rock ’n’ roll chameleon who worked with artists as varied as Madonna, Jerry Lee Lewis and Jonathan Richman, and who helped resuscitate the career of the Beach Boys mastermind Brian Wilson after his much-chronicled emotional flameout, died on Nov. 20 in Colchester, Vt. He was 73.
snippet: Musician, singer, songwriter, producer and more, he collaborated with Madonna and a raft of other artists and helped resuscitate the career of the Beach Boys’ Brian Wilson.

headline: Alongside Cease-Fire in Lebanon, Israeli Forces Keep Striking in Gaza
abstract: While Israel and Hezbollah were finalizing a cease-fire to halt the fighting in Lebanon, Israeli strikes killed 33 people in Gaza, according to local health authorities.
lead_paragraph: While Israel and Hezbollah have agreed to a cease-fire in Lebanon, the war in Gaza seems far from over.
snippet: While Israel and Hezbollah were finalizing a cease-fire to halt the fighting in Lebanon, Israeli strikes killed 33 people in Gaza, according to local health authorities.

headline: Trump’s Pick to Lead the N.I.H. Gets Some Things Right
abstract: The course of Bhattacharya’s tenure will depend on whether he can listen to his critics.
lead_paragraph: It’s a welcome sign that, unlike many of Donald Trump’s picks to lead parts of the nation’s health system, his pick for director of the National Institutes of Health, Jay Bhattacharya, is actually qualified. Though his record during the Covid-19 pandemic includes making catastrophically wrong predictions, he was also correct, especially later, on the need to consider the societal cost of prolonging early pandemic measures, including closures, hospital rules limiting visits, extended mask and vaccine mandates and social distancing rules.
snippet: The course of Bhattacharya’s tenure will depend on whether he can listen to his critics.

headline: Judge Dismisses Defamation Suit Against Fox News Brought by Jan. 6 Figure
abstract: The suit was brought by Ray Epps, who was falsely characterized by Tucker Carlson and others as being a government agent who instigated the violence at the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Wednesday tossed out a defamation lawsuit against Fox News brought by a man who claimed that the network’s former star host, Tucker Carlson, had falsely accused him of being a government provocateur who instigated the violence at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
snippet: The suit was brought by Ray Epps, who was falsely characterized by Tucker Carlson and others as being a government agent who instigated the violence at the Capitol.

headline: Several Trump Administration Picks Face Bomb Threats and ‘Swatting’
abstract: A Trump transition team spokeswoman said law enforcement officials had “acted quickly to ensure the safety of those who were targeted.”
lead_paragraph: Several of the people President-elect Donald J. Trump has picked to be cabinet nominees or for White House positions received threats on Tuesday night and Wednesday morning, a transition spokeswoman said.
snippet: A Trump transition team spokeswoman said law enforcement officials had “acted quickly to ensure the safety of those who were targeted.”

headline: Evelyne de Pontbriand, Champion of Biodynamic Winemaking, Dies at 73
abstract: The latest in a long line of women to run her family winery, she helped bring worldwide attention to sustainable viniculture.
lead_paragraph: Evelyne de Pontbriand, a former French teacher who had no formal experience in winemaking when she took over her family’s winery in the Loire Valley, but who nevertheless made it a leading example of organic viniculture and herself an internationally renowned voice for sustainable farming, died on Nov. 5 in Angers, France. She was 73.
snippet: The latest in a long line of women to run her family winery, she helped bring worldwide attention to sustainable viniculture.

headline: Why Do the Lions and Cowboys Play on Thanksgiving Every Year?
abstract: The short answer: tradition.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the Detroit Lions and the Dallas Cowboys will each host an N.F.L. game.
snippet: The short answer: tradition.

headline: Read the Cease-Fire Agreement
abstract: The Lebanese government released a copy of the cease-fire agreement on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The Lebanese government released a copy of the cease-fire agreement on Wednesday.
snippet: The Lebanese government released a copy of the cease-fire agreement on Wednesday.

headline: A Guide to N.Y.C. Holiday Events: Music, Lights and More
abstract: “The Nutcracker,” light displays and ice skating: Here are some of our favorite things to do this season.
lead_paragraph: The holidays have arrived in New York City. Festivities of all sorts, from annual classics like “The Nutcracker” to ice skating and twinkling light displays, are opening for the season. Here’s a list of shows and events to attend.
snippet: “The Nutcracker,” light displays and ice skating: Here are some of our favorite things to do this season.

headline: French Intellectuals Decry a Dissident Writer’s Arrest in Algeria
abstract: An outspoken French-Algerian novelist returned to his homeland and was promptly taken into custody at age 75.
lead_paragraph: The arrest of an outspoken writer who flew back to his Algerian homeland and was quietly taken into custody upon arrival has set off alarm in literary and political circles worldwide and threatens to trigger a diplomatic incident.
snippet: An outspoken French-Algerian novelist returned to his homeland and was promptly taken into custody at age 75.

headline: Moscow Expels 2 German Journalists, Accusing Berlin of Closing Russian TV Bureau
abstract: The German government denied it had taken action against Russia’s Channel One office in Berlin but said two Russian journalists no longer had residency permits.
lead_paragraph: Germany and Russia engaged in tit-for-tat blows over news media freedom on Wednesday, with each country making moves to expel two of the other country’s journalists.
snippet: The German government denied it had taken action against Russia’s Channel One office in Berlin but said two Russian journalists no longer had residency permits.

headline: The Triumph of the Gobbler Sandwich
abstract: The classic Thanksgiving leftovers sandwich has cultivated a whole new fan base at chain stores like Wawa.
lead_paragraph: In a 1915 essay in a trade journal encouraging candy store owners to broaden their offerings with “dainty, quick lunch” options, the writer Frank B. Kahn recommended adding a “Thanksgiving Sandwich special” of turkey meat, cranberry sauce and mayonnaise to menus. “Be sure this is seasoned right,” he wrote, “and advertise well.”
snippet: The classic Thanksgiving leftovers sandwich has cultivated a whole new fan base at chain stores like Wawa.

headline: Pakistan’s Capital Is Turned Upside Down by Unending Protests
abstract: Residents of Islamabad are tiring of regular demonstrations demanding the release of the former prime minister Imran Khan, with the marches leading to clashes with security forces.
lead_paragraph: Another anti-government protest had come and gone in Pakistan’s once peaceful capital, and Saira Bano was ready to get her city back.
snippet: Residents of Islamabad are tiring of regular demonstrations demanding the release of the former prime minister Imran Khan, with the marches leading to clashes with security forces.

headline: Manfred Ohrenstein, Liberal Lion of N.Y. Legislature, Dies at 99
abstract: He entered the State Senate as a reformer but during 34 years became part of the system he sought to reform.
lead_paragraph: Manfred Ohrenstein, a fiery reformer who, while relegated to the Democratic minority of the New York State Senate for 34 years, successfully championed progressive legislation that safeguarded rent controls, legalized abortion and repealed the death penalty, died on Nov. 18 at his home in Manhattan. He was 99.
snippet: He entered the State Senate as a reformer but during 34 years became part of the system he sought to reform.

headline: Musk’s Slashing of the Federal Budget Faces Big Hurdles
abstract: The so-called Department of Government Efficiency, with Elon Musk as co-leader, has advantages that past budget-cutters did not, but laws and court challenges can still make change slow and difficult.
lead_paragraph: These are frenzied times for the nascent Department of Government Efficiency.
snippet: The so-called Department of Government Efficiency, with Elon Musk as co-leader, has advantages that past budget-cutters did not, but laws and court challenges can still make change slow and difficult.

headline: The False Premise Shaping Trump’s Public Health Picks
abstract: Nobody got Covid totally right. But the contrarians got it mostly wrong.
lead_paragraph: To look at the short list of names Donald Trump is hoping to appoint to the country’s leading public health roles, it’s easy to see that Covid-19 has remade the country and its ideological arrangements — but perhaps especially the Republican Party.
snippet: Nobody got Covid totally right. But the contrarians got it mostly wrong.

headline: Trump Picks Keith Kellogg to Be Envoy to Ukraine and Russia
abstract: The retired Army lieutenant general could play a key role in any negotiations to end the yearslong war between the countries.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Wednesday that his envoy to Russia and Ukraine would be Keith Kellogg, a retired lieutenant general who was a national security adviser to Vice President Mike Pence during the first Trump administration.
snippet: The retired Army lieutenant general could play a key role in any negotiations to end the yearslong war between the countries.

headline: Am I a Hypocrite for Calling Donald Trump a Liar?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on hypocrisy.
lead_paragraph: My Trump-supporter friends understand that he’s a liar and adulterer but adamantly defend him with reasoning like ‘‘Everyone lies — have you not lied before?’’ or ‘‘My dad’s an extremely trustworthy guy even though he cheated on my mom a couple of times — so what?’’ I understand they are rationalizing to feel good about their candidate, but is it ethical to be hypocritical? — Name Withheld
snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on hypocrisy.

headline: Black Friday May Have Lost the Chaos but It’s Still Huge for Retailers
abstract: Black Friday remains one of the busiest shopping days of the year, but its impact has been diluted by monthlong holiday sales and the convenience of buying online.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of customers camped outside a department store at the crack of dawn. A stampede for the hottest new video game console. Fisticuffs over a coveted flat-screen television.
snippet: Black Friday remains one of the busiest shopping days of the year, but its impact has been diluted by monthlong holiday sales and the convenience of buying online.

headline: Who Is Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing of Myanmar?
abstract: The country’s military leader has been accused of crimes against humanity over the army’s persecution of the Rohingya ethnic group.
lead_paragraph: The head of Myanmar’s military junta was accused on Wednesday of crimes against humanity by the International Criminal Court’s top prosecutor, in a blow to the war-torn country’s government.
snippet: The country’s military leader has been accused of crimes against humanity over the army’s persecution of the Rohingya ethnic group.

headline: Thursday Briefing: A Fragile Cease-fire in Lebanon
abstract: Plus, a post-election Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: The Lebanese Army said yesterday that it was sending more forces to southern Lebanon to support a U.S.-backed cease-fire agreement between Israel and Hezbollah as it began to take hold.
snippet: Plus, a post-election Thanksgiving.

headline: Tran Defeats Steel in House Pickup for Democrats
abstract: Derek Tran, a consumer rights lawyer and Army veteran, defeated Representative Michelle Steel, a Republican two-term incumbent, flipping a seat in Orange County, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Derek Tran, a consumer rights lawyer and Army veteran, defeated Representative Michelle Steel, a Republican two-term incumbent, according to The Associated Press, flipping a battleground seat in Orange County, Calif.
snippet: Derek Tran, a consumer rights lawyer and Army veteran, defeated Representative Michelle Steel, a Republican two-term incumbent, flipping a seat in Orange County, Calif.

headline: Helen Gallagher, Winner of Two Tonys and Three Emmys, Dies at 98
abstract: She was honored on Broadway for roles in “Pal Joey” and “No, No, Nanette” and then turned to TV, where she won three Daytime Emmys for her work on “Ryan’s Hope.”
lead_paragraph: Helen Gallagher, who parlayed her song-and-dance skills into Tony Award-winning performances in revivals of the musicals “Pal Joey” and “No, No, Nanette,” and who turned to television to play the matriarch on the long-running soap opera “Ryan’s Hope” when theater no longer provided her a living, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 98.
snippet: She was honored on Broadway for roles in “Pal Joey” and “No, No, Nanette” and then turned to TV, where she won three Daytime Emmys for her work on “Ryan’s Hope.”

headline: Northern Israel Somber as a Few Soldiers and Residents Trickle Through
abstract: While there were limited signs of life in the area, most residents were hesitant to head back without greater certainty that the cease-fire with Hezbollah would hold.
lead_paragraph: A truck was transporting an Israeli tank returned from Lebanon. Residents were visiting their damaged homes near the border for the first time in a year. Israeli soldiers were bathing in a natural hot spring in the rain, in an area where sirens screamed the previous night.
snippet: While there were limited signs of life in the area, most residents were hesitant to head back without greater certainty that the cease-fire with Hezbollah would hold.

headline: Rain Expected at Macy’s Thanksgiving Parade
abstract: Over half an inch of rain could accumulate throughout Thursday in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Spectators attending Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade on Thursday can expect light, steady rain throughout the event, according to the National Weather Service.
snippet: Over half an inch of rain could accumulate throughout Thursday in Manhattan.

headline: Thousands Stream Homeward as Fragile Peace Begins in Lebanon
abstract: The cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah began on Wednesday, but much hardship and uncertainty lie ahead after a yearlong war that killed thousands and left widespread destruction in Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of civilians began the journey back to their war-ravaged, mostly abandoned communities around Beirut and in southern Lebanon on Wednesday, as a U.S.-backed cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah took tenuous hold after more than 13 months of bloodshed.
snippet: The cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah began on Wednesday, but much hardship and uncertainty lie ahead after a yearlong war that killed thousands and left widespread destruction in Lebanon.

headline: What We Know About the Cease-Fire in Lebanon
abstract: The truce began Wednesday, bringing a fragile peace to Israel and Lebanon. Israeli troops are to withdraw in phases  from southern Lebanon, and Lebanese military convoys headed south to protect the peace.
lead_paragraph: A cease-fire agreement to end the conflict between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon went into effect on Wednesday morning, bringing a fragile peace to an area that has seen more than a year of fighting.
snippet: The truce began Wednesday, bringing a fragile peace to Israel and Lebanon. Israeli troops are to withdraw in phases  from southern Lebanon, and Lebanese military convoys headed south to protect the peace.

headline: Robert Dixon, Last Surviving Buffalo Soldier, Dies at 103
abstract: A member of one of the U.S. Army’s all-Black regiments, formed after the Civil War, he trained West Point cadets in horsemanship during World War II.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Robert W. Dixon Sr., the last known survivor of the U.S. Army’s all-Black regiments known as Buffalo Soldiers, died on Nov. 15 near Albany, N.Y. He was 103.
snippet: A member of one of the U.S. Army’s all-Black regiments, formed after the Civil War, he trained West Point cadets in horsemanship during World War II.

headline: Thousands of Lebanese Head South as a Fragile Peace Begins
abstract: Also, Trump picked an envoy for Russia and Ukraine. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Roads heading south of Beirut were packed with bumper-to-bumper traffic today as thousands of people returned to war-ravaged towns. The movement came as a cease-fire began to take effect between Israel and Hezbollah after more than 13 months of bloodshed.
snippet: Also, Trump picked an envoy for Russia and Ukraine. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.

headline: Schools in Gaza Bombed During Cease-Fire in Lebanon
abstract: Gazans searched through the rubble after an Israeli strike hit two schools serving as shelters for the displaced.
lead_paragraph: Gazans searched through the rubble after an Israeli strike hit two schools serving as shelters for the displaced.
snippet: Gazans searched through the rubble after an Israeli strike hit two schools serving as shelters for the displaced.

headline: Sean Combs Is Denied Bail a Third Time
abstract: A federal judge ruled against the music mogul’s efforts to be released from jail while he awaits trial on sex trafficking and racketeering charges.
lead_paragraph: Sean Combs, the embattled music mogul who has been charged with sex trafficking and racketeering, was denied bail again on Wednesday after a federal judge rejected his lawyers’ third attempt to challenge his detention.
snippet: A federal judge ruled against the music mogul’s efforts to be released from jail while he awaits trial on sex trafficking and racketeering charges.

headline: Lebanese and Israelis Return to Their Homes Following Cease-Fire
abstract: Ramez Hassan Boustany checked on his home in the southern suburbs of Beirut following the cease-fire agreement between Israel and Hezbollah. In northern Israel, Amichay Bitton surveyed the damage on his parents’ property.
lead_paragraph: Ramez Hassan Boustany checked on his home in the southern suburbs of Beirut following the cease-fire agreement between Israel and Hezbollah. In northern Israel, Amichay Bitton surveyed the damage on his parents’ property.
snippet: Ramez Hassan Boustany checked on his home in the southern suburbs of Beirut following the cease-fire agreement between Israel and Hezbollah. In northern Israel, Amichay Bitton surveyed the damage on his parents’ property.

headline: Youth Pastor Charged With Nearly 200 Sex Crimes Going Back Decades
abstract: Many of the victims were the West Virginia pastor’s relatives, the police said, including five nieces who filed a complaint against him in 2004.
lead_paragraph: The state police in West Virginia are continuing to investigate a longtime youth pastor who has now been charged with nearly 200 counts of sexual abuse crimes involving children, many of them his relatives, dating back more than three decades.
snippet: Many of the victims were the West Virginia pastor’s relatives, the police said, including five nieces who filed a complaint against him in 2004.

headline: F.T.C. Launches Antitrust Investigation Into Microsoft
abstract: Regulators are demanding information from the company on its cloud computing, artificial intelligence and cybersecurity products.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission has opened an investigation into whether Microsoft has violated antitrust law in multiple segments of its wide-ranging business, according to two people familiar with the inquiry, the latest salvo in a battle by the government to rein in the most powerful tech companies.
snippet: Regulators are demanding information from the company on its cloud computing, artificial intelligence and cybersecurity products.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Detective Is Charged With Making ‘Ghost Guns’
abstract: Anthony Sciortino, a detective in Staten Island, was also charged with falsifying police records in what prosecutors said was a “brazen act of misconduct.”
lead_paragraph: A New York City police detective has been arrested and accused of amassing a small arsenal of unregistered firearms, prosecutors said.
snippet: Anthony Sciortino, a detective in Staten Island, was also charged with falsifying police records in what prosecutors said was a “brazen act of misconduct.”

headline: John Fetterman Wants Democrats to Stop Freaking Out
abstract: “Buckle up and pack a lunch, because it’s going to be four years of this,” the Democratic senator from Pennsylvania said.
lead_paragraph: Senator John Fetterman wasn’t in Washington for the first Trump administration. But he has a few ideas about how Democrats should handle the second.
snippet: “Buckle up and pack a lunch, because it’s going to be four years of this,” the Democratic senator from Pennsylvania said.

headline: A Year of War Transformed Hezbollah
abstract: Israel has decimated Hezbollah’s senior leadership and military infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: Wars have a transformative impact on the parties that fight them. That was certainly the case the last time Israel and Hezbollah engaged in all-out conflict back in July 2006. Hezbollah emerged from that fight — which lasted just over a month — battered but defiant after standing up to the most powerful military in the Middle East. That experience, along with Iranian support, set Hezbollah up to make significant strides militarily and politically in the years that followed, transforming it into a transnational organization equipped with an estimated 150,000 rockets and missiles while also being represented by lawmakers in Lebanon’s Parliament.
snippet: Israel has decimated Hezbollah’s senior leadership and military infrastructure.

headline: U.S. Border Agents Seize 3,000 Fake Gibson Guitars
abstract: They would have been worth nearly $18 million if they were genuine, making it the largest counterfeit instrument seizure in history, officials said.
lead_paragraph: At a glance, the Gibson guitars look like some of the most coveted six-stringed instruments in the world, including signature models played by Dave Grohl that sell for up to $10,000 and some that looked as if they had been autographed by Slash.
snippet: They would have been worth nearly $18 million if they were genuine, making it the largest counterfeit instrument seizure in history, officials said.

headline: ‘Queer’ Review: The Seductive, Damaged Charm of Daniel Craig
abstract: The star kills off his Bond to inhabit a dissolute American expat in Luca Guadagnino’s handsome adaptation of the William S. Burroughs novella.
lead_paragraph: When William Lee stalks through Mexico City in “Queer,” he often seems on high alert, though sometimes he’s just high. The louche protagonist in Luca Guadagnino’s soft-serve adaptation of the William S. Burroughs autobiographical novella, Lee is a smoker, drinker, heroin addict and epic storyteller. He’s a refugee from America who at times seems like a visitor from another dimension. Played with sensitivity and predatory heat by Daniel Craig, Lee has a feverish mind, eyes like searchlights and a mouth that’s quick to sneer. There are moments when he seems possessed, though it’s not often clear what’s taken hold of his soul.
snippet: The star kills off his Bond to inhabit a dissolute American expat in Luca Guadagnino’s handsome adaptation of the William S. Burroughs novella.
